name.text: 10.4.2.1 Finding the roots of complex numbers

questiontext.text:
Finding the roots of complex numbers

In this subsection we ask if we can obtain fractional powers of complex numbers; for example what are the values of \(8^{1/3}\), \((-24)^{1/4}\) or even \((1+i)^{1/2}\)?

More precisely, for these three examples, we are asking for those values of \(z\) which satisfy \[\qquad z^3-8=0\qquad\text{or}\qquad z^4+24=0\qquad\text{or}\qquad z^2-(1+i)=0\] Each of these problems involve finding roots of a complex number.

To solve problems such as these we need to be more careful with our interpretation of arg\((z)\) for a given complex number \(z\).

Revisiting arg\((z)\)

By definition, arg\((z)\) is the angle made by the line representing \(z\) with the positive \(x\)-axis. See (a) in the figure below. However, figure (b) below shows you can increase \(\theta\) by \(2\pi\) (\(360^{\circ}\)) and still obtain the same line in the \(xy\) plane. In general, as indicated in figure (c), any integer multiple of \(2\pi\) can be added to or subtracted from arg\((z)\) without affecting the Cartesian form of the complex number.



Key Point

arg\((z)\) is unique only up to an integer multiple of \(2\pi\).


For example: \[\qquad z=1+i=\sqrt{2}\left(\cos{\pi \over 4}+i\sin{\pi\over 4}\right)\]

in polar form.

However, we could also write: \[\qquad z=1+i=\sqrt{2}\left(\cos\left({\pi \over 4}+2\pi\right)+i\sin\left({\pi\over 4}+2\pi\right)\right)\] or in full generality:\[\qquad z=1+i=\sqrt{2}\left(\cos\left({\pi \over 4}+2k\pi\right)+i\sin\left({\pi\over 4}+2k\pi\right)\right)\qquad k=0,\pm 1,\pm 2,\ldots\]This last expression shows that in the polar form of a complex number, the argument of \(z\), arg\((z)\), can take infinitely many different values, each one differing by an integer multiple of \(2\pi\). This is nothing more than a consequence of the well-known properties of the trigonometric functions: \[\qquad \cos(\theta +2k\pi )\equiv\cos\theta,\qquad \sin(\theta +2k\pi)\equiv\sin\theta\]for any integer \(k\).

We will now show how we can use this more general interpretation of arg\((z)\) in the process of finding roots.
